text: The sky beyond the North Gate looks as though it has been poured over with molten iron—heavy and black. Wind drives snow against armor in sharp, scraping bursts.
The barrier is reduced to a thin layer of blue light, like dying skin clinging to the outer wall, flickering between bright and dim.
The soldiers crowd behind the final defensive line, shields layered over shields, breath spilling out in white clouds. No one speaks—they are waiting.
Alicia steps to the very front. Her cloak snaps straight in the wind, her cracked sword seeming to grind its teeth.
She doesn’t look back for reassurance, doesn’t offer comfort. She simply raises a hand—signaling everyone to hold the formation she drilled into them.
The movement is practiced to perfection: one step, half-step, another—fitting precisely into the seam between wind and terrain.

From the depths of the rift, the Demon King’s silhouette rises. It seems pieced together from black mist, bone armor, and fragments of a shattered throne. In its chest yawns a hollow core, light within it writhing like something alive.
Each time it ‘breathes,’ the snow collapses in rings, stones rattling upward before crashing back down.
The Demon King speaks, its voice layered with countless whispers: “Re—turn—”
The blue barrier ripples under that sound, like water struck by a boulder.
Alicia does not answer. She lifts her blade and points it toward the core—pinning the ‘ending’ to that single point.
“Don’t look at its face. Look at its core.”

She launches forward. Not reckless, but terrifyingly precise—crushing the first rising stone underfoot, using it to leap over the second collapsing ring, landing exactly in the Demon King’s blind spot.
Her first strike arcs in silver, cleaving open the outer layer of mist. It shrieks like torn flesh.
The Demon King’s claw sweeps sideways, carving five cracks through the air.
Alicia slides low, cloak skimming the snow, barely evading the talons.
Her second strike doesn’t cut mist—it cuts the gap. The blade pierces a hairline fracture along the core’s edge. Black light bursts outward like a wounded eye.
The recoil slams into her arm, shattering a plate of armor. She grunts—but does not retreat.
The Demon King roars. Its bone armor splits, black ripples spilling outward, draining warmth from the snow as they pass.
The ripple surges toward the defensive line—some soldiers nearly collapse.
Alicia pivots, slicing sideways—not cutting energy, but cutting its path.
The ripple bends, grazing the shield wall before detonating against the city walls in an explosion of stone.
She shifts disaster away with her own positioning.
“Hold your ground!”
The Demon King raises another claw—not striking, but pressing, as if to shove her back into the rift and force her to ‘return.’
She blocks, knee slamming into the snow, carving a deep crater.
The pressure bursts her shoulder guard. Blood seeps down her gauntlet, black against the snow.
She grits her teeth—and steps forward into the crushing weight.
Her third strike rises from below, blade tracing the fracture in the core, tearing it open further.
The core contracts violently, black light writhing as if to swallow her sword. She jerks it free, her arm scorched.
A spine-like tail of condensed mist lashes toward her.
She leaps, lands atop the writhing spine, and uses its motion to vault higher—like riding a wave.
Midair, she adjusts, blade aimed directly at the core from above.
Her fourth strike plunges downward, piercing through the mist’s outer layer and pinning the core’s edge. Black light blossoms like a dark flower.
But the Demon King learns in that same instant. The mist spirals around her blade, trying to bind her whole body.
She lands. Black mist coils around her ankle, cold like fingers on bone.
She doesn’t resist. Instead, she gives in to the pull—letting it drag her directly before the core.
It is the most dangerous position. It is also the only one.
“…Finally opened the door.”
She tears open the clasp inside her cloak and draws out the necklace—the Echo Order leader’s token. The pendant burns in the black light.
The Demon King senses termination. The mist surges violently toward her wrist.
It only needs to steal that instant for the loop to continue.
Her fingers tremble—exhaustion crashing down at the worst moment.
And in that instant, someone breaks from the defensive line behind her.

options.text: Option A: Loudly declare your love for Alicia 【DC 10 Charisma】
Option B: Shout at the monster and throw a stone to draw its attention and create an opening 【DC 10 Strength】
